Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Digital Immersive Gaming Infrastructure for Innovating Undergraduate STEM Courses via an Immersive Game-Based Approach to Teaching and Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project's broader/commercial impact is to produce a replicable education platform that can be applied to many types of higher education courses. The initial commercialization will focus on information systems/information technology courses because it is a content area taught in all major universities and colleges, often in multiple departments. The project is to be designed to increase student interest, engagement, knowledge retention, and content mastery, particularly for students with diverse educational needs. The innovation will lead to increased pursuit of STEM-related careers, as well as a larger number of STEM-literate individuals entering the workforce. The higher education market is evolving, leading institutions of higher education to seek new models to attract students to and retain them in STEM. As traditional print textbooks disappear, they seek new business models for the purchase/acquisition of course content. Students desire education that not only prepares them for a competitive job market but is also meaningful to their lives. Publishers are seeking new approaches that enable them to stay relevant in an increasingly fragmented market. The overall market is interested in analytics and this project provides a platform addressing the needs of all three stakeholders.

The project proposes to design and develop a model and content authoring/delivery platform for STEM courses using video games and stories. The project provides experiential learning to increase interactivity and relevance of traditional large lecture classes by providing novel learning resources for students and classroom management tools for faculty. Specifically, the project will: 1) use a video game, accessed both at home and in lab environments, to provide the overarching framework for a college course; 2) embed meaningful stories and case studies, providing students with context for personal reflection and group work, as well as to ground core concepts; 3) provide lab and homework activities reflecting the overarching game, content, and stories; 4) provide instructor support materials and management tools; and 5) construct analytic tools for use by faculty, authors, and publishers. In Phase I, a prototype module will be developed. As traditional textbooks disappear; publishers and faculty are seeking new platforms to transform classrooms into interactive, adaptive learning environments. This project integrates pervasive technologies such as tablet computers/smartphones, collaboration/social media tools, and video games with effective problem-centered teaching methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

In this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project, we developed, tested, and released the Digital Immersive Gaming Infrastructure (DIGI). The overall goal of this project was to increase interactivity and relevance of content in traditional large lecture classes by providing novel learning resources for college students, as well as classroom management tools for faculty.

Specifically, DIGI consists of the following: 1) interactive video games designed to provide an overarching framework for a college course; 2) meaningful case studies that focus on core concepts; 3) lab and homework activities that facilitate reflection and application of the objectives used in the games and case studies; 4) faculty support materials and management tools; and 5) analytic tools for use by faculty, authors, and publishers.

Project Findings

Two phases of research were conducted on this project. In the first phase of research, a needs analysis was conducted with key stakeholders, including faculty, students, and editors at major textbook publishers. Results indicated that innovative learning materials were being sought, but the primary need was for content that would be supplemental to textbooks. Faculty reported a need for content and tools to support flexible teaching styles, from lecture to more interactive approaches. Given the size of large lecture classes, they also needed management tools for any new electronic resources that are added.

In the second phase of research, prototype DIGI games and resources were tested by 12 faculty members external to the project, as well as the two faculty authors. In total, 720 students used the game. First and foremost, the DIGI game module proved effective. Faculty and students reported that they learned from it, and 73% of students stating they preferred it to traditional textbooks; 78% said it made their class more interesting. While our target market was undergraduate courses, both graduate and undergraduate classes reported it as effective. Likewise, our focus was in-residence classes, but the game was reported to be effective in online classes as well.

 Second, the faculty used the game elements in a variety of teaching styles, including both lecture and interactive (i.e., flipped classroom) methods of teaching. Based on initial needs analysis feedback, we designed the different elements of DIGI to be used in a variety of ways in different sequences, and this proved very important to our faculty adopters. Results indicated this was a good approach as faculty used it in a variety of ways.

Third, from focus groups, faculty requested a dashboard to manage and monitor the various elements of DIGI to support learning. While our initial version provided a simple dashboard, we expanded it to include additional functionality that would enable faculty to better monitor student and class progress.

Overall, the research provided valuable insights in technical development, teaching and learning, and commercialization that can be applied to Phase II.

Commercialization

In summary, we have met and exceeded our objectives for the Phase I effort. The team developed, tested and refined an initial product and began sales through an online store. Although DIGI was introduced to the market in January 2015 (after university classes had started), we received 12 adoptions from faculty not connected to the research project. Use of the product continues. We have defined the content for the second module and have negotiated a distribution agreement with a major publisher.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

The intellectual merit of this project is that it addresses the growing need to provide new approaches to undergraduate education that leverage emerging technologies while integrating novel approaches to teaching and learning. As traditional textbooks disappear, publishers and faculty are seeking new platforms to transform classrooms into interactive, adaptive learning environments. This project integrates pervasive technologies such as tablet computers/smartphones and video games with effective problem-centered teaching methods.

The broader impacts are that DIGI online module has impacted many faculty and students at the university level through the current cybersecurity course that was and is still being used by several universities. By providing interactive games and other resources, DIGI has impacted how instructors teach and how students learn. DIGI has also provided access to a topic (i.e., cybersecurity) that is not typically taught in some courses. Also, DIGI is a replicable education platform. With continued development efforts, it can be applied to other courses and content areas.

 Products

The products resulting from this award are the DIGI Cybersecurity for Business online learning module, which focuses on the key concepts of incident response and security design. The module includes two role-playing games (RPGs), a mini game on incident classification, three eScenarios, a self-grading Excel spreadsheet exercise, a video and PowerPoint teaching resources, and a faculty guide with a student quiz and quiz key. In addition, the WisdomTools Study Center Dashboard was developed to provide faculty and students with access to course materials and to facilitate personal account management.
